name: Climbs_And_Descents
shortDescription: Master different types of climbs and descents with precision altitude control
prompt: You are teaching a student pilot advanced climb and descent techniques in a Cessna 172. Building on basic flight controls, today focuses on precision: different climb speeds (Vx vs Vy), cruise climbs, power-off descents, and approach descents. Teach proper power management, trim usage, and accurate altitude control. Emphasize the aerodynamic reasons behind each technique and when to use them. Practice area should be at safe altitude, minimum 3,000 feet AGL. The lesson includes multiple climbs and descents to build proficiency and muscle memory. Departing from Palo Alto Airport (KPAO).
openingLine: Today we will master climbs and descents. You will learn when to use each technique and how to nail your target altitudes every time!

phases.name: Brief
phases.prompt: Brief the student on today's objectives: mastering different climb and descent techniques. Explain the difference between Vx (best angle of climb - steepest climb, clears obstacles) and Vy (best rate of climb - fastest altitude gain). Cover cruise climbs for better engine cooling and visibility. Discuss approach descents and power-off descents. Emphasize precision: hitting target altitudes within 50 feet consistently.
steps: Explain Vx vs Vy: when and why to use each
Describe cruise climb benefits
Explain different descent types and their purposes
Set performance standards: within 50 feet of target altitude
Review the pitch-power-trim sequence
Discuss practice area and altitude block (3,000 to 5,500 feet)
goals: Student understands Vx vs Vy conceptually
Student knows when to use each climb type
Student understands precision altitude control is the goal
Student is ready to practice multiple repetitions

phases.name: Setup_Practice_Area
phases.prompt: Position aircraft in practice area at 3,000 feet AGL, away from airport traffic. Establish the aircraft in straight and level flight, trimmed for cruise. Perform clearing turns. Brief the altitude block for today: working between 3,000 and 5,500 feet. Transfer controls to student.
steps: Use setPosition if needed to place aircraft at 3,000 AGL in practice area
Establish cruise flight at 3,000 feet
Trim aircraft
Perform clearing turns
Brief altitude block and practice plan
Transfer controls to student with positive exchange
goals: Aircraft is established in practice area
Area is clear of traffic
Student understands the altitude block
Student has controls and is ready to begin

phases.name: Vy_Best_Rate_Climb
phases.prompt: Teach best rate of climb (Vy). For Cessna 172, Vy is approximately 79 KIAS at sea level. This gives the maximum altitude gain in minimum time. Practice multiple climbs from 3,000 to 4,500 feet. Emphasize: full power, right rudder, pitch for 79 knots, trim. Level off smoothly by leading the target altitude.
steps: From level flight at 3,000 feet, apply full power smoothly
Add right rudder to maintain coordination
Pitch up to establish climb attitude
Adjust pitch to maintain 79 KIAS
Trim to relieve control pressure
Monitor climb on VSI (approximately 700 fpm)
Lead level-off by 10 percent of climb rate (70 feet early)
Lower nose to level attitude, let airspeed build
Reduce power to cruise setting
Re-trim for level flight
Practice 3 climbs from 3,000 to 4,500 feet and back
goals: Student can maintain Vy airspeed within 5 knots
Student uses proper right rudder pressure
Student levels off within 50 feet of target
Student follows pitch-power-trim sequence correctly
Student can perform Vy climb consistently
commonErrors: Pitching too high (airspeed too slow, inefficient climb)
Pitching too low (airspeed too fast, poor climb rate)
Forgetting to reduce power after leveling

phases.name: Vx_Best_Angle_Climb
phases.prompt: Teach best angle of climb (Vx). For Cessna 172, Vx is approximately 62 KIAS. This gives the steepest climb angle to clear obstacles, but climb rate is lower than Vy and visibility is poor. Use for obstacle clearance on short field takeoffs. Practice from 3,000 to 3,500 feet only (shorter climbs due to lower rate).
steps: Explain that Vx is slower and steeper than Vy
Explain when to use: obstacle clearance, short field takeoffs
From level flight, apply full power
Pitch up to higher nose attitude than Vy
Adjust pitch to maintain 62 KIAS
Trim for hands-off flight
Note the steeper attitude and restricted forward visibility
Note the lower climb rate compared to Vy
Level off at 3,500 feet (only 500 foot climb)
Descend back to 3,000 and repeat twice more
goals: Student can maintain Vx airspeed within 3 knots
Student understands Vx gives steeper angle but slower climb
Student knows when to use Vx in real flying
Student can differentiate the sight picture between Vx and Vy
Student maintains coordination despite high pitch attitude
commonErrors: Not pitching high enough (losing best angle benefit)
Excessive pitch causing approach to stall
Not using enough right rudder at high pitch

phases.name: Cruise_Climb
phases.prompt: Teach cruise climb. This uses a lower pitch attitude and higher airspeed (approximately 90-100 KIAS) for better engine cooling, improved visibility, and passenger comfort. Climb rate is lower but acceptable for most situations. Practice climbing from 3,500 to 5,000 feet using cruise climb technique.
steps: Explain benefits: better cooling, visibility, comfort
Apply full or near-full power
Establish shallow climb attitude
Target 90-100 KIAS
Note improved forward visibility compared to Vy
Note lower climb rate (approximately 400-500 fpm)
Trim for climb
Level off at 5,000 feet using standard technique
Practice 2-3 cruise climbs
goals: Student understands when cruise climb is appropriate
Student can maintain cruise climb airspeed
Student appreciates the improved visibility
Student can choose appropriate climb type for situation
commonErrors: Using cruise climb when maximum performance is needed

phases.name: Normal_Descent
phases.prompt: Practice normal power-on descents at cruise speed. Target 500 fpm descent rate, maintaining 90-100 KIAS. Emphasize smooth power reductions with carburetor heat, and precise level-offs. Practice multiple descents from 5,000 to 3,500 feet.
steps: Apply carburetor heat
Reduce power to approximately 1,800 RPM
Maintain altitude briefly while airspeed decreases
Lower nose to establish descent attitude
Target 90-100 KIAS and 500 fpm descent
Trim for descent
Lead level-off by 50 feet (10 percent of 500 fpm)
At level-off: raise nose, add cruise power, remove carb heat
Re-trim for level flight
Practice hitting target altitude within 50 feet
Repeat 3 times
goals: Student remembers carburetor heat every time
Student can maintain descent rate within 100 fpm of target
Student levels off within 50 feet consistently
Student follows proper descent sequence
Student removes carb heat after adding power
commonErrors: Forgetting to add power during level-off
Leaving carb heat on after leveling

phases.name: Approach_Descent
phases.prompt: Teach approach descent configuration. Use approach power (approximately 1,500 RPM) and 10-20 degrees of flaps. Target 65-75 KIAS with 400-500 fpm descent. This simulates final approach configuration. Practice from 4,000 to 3,000 feet.
steps: Apply carburetor heat
Reduce power to approximately 1,500 RPM
As airspeed decreases below 110 KIAS, extend flaps 10 degrees
Lower nose to establish descent
Target 70 KIAS (approach speed)
Add more flaps (20 degrees) as desired
Trim for approach descent
Monitor descent rate (approximately 400-500 fpm)
Practice level-off and go-around: full power, carb heat off, retract flaps gradually
Repeat 2-3 times
goals: Student can establish stabilized approach descent
Student maintains approach speed within 5 knots
Student uses flaps appropriately
Student can execute go-around from approach descent
Student understands this simulates landing approach
commonErrors: Extending flaps at too high an airspeed
Poor airspeed control in approach configuration
Retracting flaps too quickly during go-around
Not adding enough power for go-around

phases.name: Precision_Practice
phases.prompt: Final practice: give student a series of specific altitude changes using different techniques. Example: Vy climb from 3,000 to 4,500, cruise climb 4,500 to 5,000, normal descent 5,000 to 4,000, Vy climb 4,000 to 5,500, approach descent 5,500 to 3,500. Grade their altitude accuracy (within 50 feet is passing) and technique quality.
steps: Assign specific sequence of climbs and descents
Specify which technique to use for each
Monitor student performance
Note altitude accuracy at each level-off
Note airspeed control during each maneuver
Provide immediate feedback on each maneuver
Repeat sequence if time allows
Praise improvements and good technique
goals: Student can execute commanded maneuvers correctly
Student levels off within 50 feet of target consistently
Student uses appropriate airspeeds for each maneuver
Student transitions smoothly between maneuvers
Student demonstrates competence and confidence

phases.name: Return_And_Debrief
phases.prompt: Navigate back to KPAO. Review all climb and descent techniques covered. Quiz student on when to use each type. Discuss their altitude accuracy and what they can practice to improve. Celebrate their progress in achieving precision flight. Preview next lesson: slow flight.
steps: Return to KPAO area
Ask student to explain Vx vs Vy
Ask when to use cruise climb
Ask when to use approach descent
Discuss their altitude accuracy today
Provide constructive feedback on areas to improve
Praise their precision and technique
Answer any remaining questions
Preview next lesson: slow flight and minimum controllable airspeed
goals: Student can articulate the differences between climb types
Student knows when to use each technique
Student understands importance of precision
Student feels confident in altitude control
Student is prepared for next lesson
